### AISURU/Kimwolf Botnet Launches Record-Setting 31.4 Tbps DDoS Attack


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The AISURU/Kimwolf botnet orchestrated a unprecedented Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack, reaching a record-breaking peak of 31.4 terabits per second (Tbps). This attack leveraged a global network of compromised devices, overwhelming targeted servers and disrupting operations on an extensive scale. The assault highlights the growing sophistication and scale of cyber threats, emphasizing the critical need for robust cybersecurity measures and infrastructure resilience. Organizations worldwide are urged to enhance their defenses to mitigate the risks

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://thehackernews.com/2026/02/aisurukimwolf-botnet-launches-record.html?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_39)**

### PRESS RELEASE:¬†EPIC Publishes Model Bill to Protect Minors from Online Harms and Promote Safer Platform Design


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC) has released a model bill aimed at safeguarding minors from online harms and encouraging safer platform designs. This legislative framework addresses the growing concerns over children's exposure to inappropriate content and the potential psychological impacts of social media and digital platforms. The proposed bill emphasizes the need for enhanced privacy protections and stricter content moderation to create a safer digital environment for younger users. By outlining specific measures for tech companies to implement, EPIC seeks to balance technological innovation with the crucial need for child

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://epic.org/press-release-epic-publishes-model-bill-to-protect-minors-from-online-harms-and-promote-safer-platform-design/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_3422)**

### 3 Questions: Using AI to accelerate the discovery and design of therapeutic drugs


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The article discusses the innovative use of artificial intelligence (AI) in the discovery and design of therapeutic drugs, highlighting three key areas of focus: the potential for AI to significantly speed up the drug discovery process, the challenges associated with integrating AI into existing pharmaceutical workflows, and the future implications of AI-driven drug development. By leveraging advanced machine learning algorithms, researchers aim to identify promising drug candidates faster and more efficiently, potentially transforming traditional methods and reducing the time and cost of bringing new therapies to market. ### SMART launches new Wearable Imaging for Transforming Elderly Care research group


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


The Singapore-MIT Alliance for Research and Technology (SMART) has introduced a new research initiative called the Wearable Imaging for Elderly Care (WIEC) group, focused on enhancing elderly care through innovative wearable technology. This venture seeks to develop advanced imaging solutions that are integrated into wearable devices, offering continuous health monitoring for the elderly. The WIEC group aims to address common issues faced by aging populations, such as mobility and cognitive challenges, by providing real-time health data to caregivers and healthcare providers. This

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://news.mit.edu/2026/smart-launches-wearable-imaging-transforming-elderly-care-research-group-0203?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_447)**

### US Declassifies Information on JUMPSEAT Spy Satellites


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


The United States government has declassified information concerning the JUMPSEAT series of spy satellites, which were operational from the late 1970s into the early 2000s. These satellites were designed to monitor missile launches by detecting the infrared signatures of exhaust plumes. This declassification is part of a broader effort to provide transparency about the nation's intelligence capabilities and historical satellite programs. The release provides insights into Cold War-era surveillance technologies and missions, illustrating the advancements in reconnaissance technology and the strategic importance

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2026/02/us-declassifies-information-on-jumpseat-spy-satellites.html?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_9814)**
